FacilityName: Mexichem Specialty Resins, Inc. - Henry Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source [40 CFR 68.155(a)]:
The Mexichem Specialty Resin Inc. (Mexichem), Henry Plant, a producer of Specialty Vinyl Chloride Resins, is fully committed to conducting operations in a manner protective of the environment that benefits both our employees and community. We will accomplish this by:

- Complying with all applicable federal, state and local regulations and permits.
- Proactively finding ways to continually improve in our environmental performance and prevent pollution through teamwork and innovation. Our efforts are supported by Mexichem Corporate Policy.
- Communicating this policy to all employees and other stakeholders, and to manage its effective implementation through employee participation and the use of an Environmental Management System.

At Mexichem and our subsidiary companies, Safety is our top priority. Importance is placed on the environment, quality of our product and services. We accomplish this by:

1.)	Preventing accidents and property damage by emphasizing that safety is everyone's responsibility
2.)	Striving for the preservation of health, safety, and security of our people
3.)	Creating Positive impact on the environment through pollution prevention, reduction of resources, consumption and recycling of waste.
4.)	Continuously improving our Management Systems, performance objectives, measuring results, reviewing and improving processes.
5.)	Communicating openly with stake holders; complying with current federal and local regulations along with external requirements and commitments that may apply.

It is the responsibility of each and every one of us to ensure that all operations in the company are carried out in accordance with this policy. Mexichem believes safety and health are the highest corporate priority. It is our policy to conduct business in a manner that ensures the safety and health of employees, customers and the communities in which we operate

. In the unlikely event of a release, the Henry plant is a responding facility for releases of the RMP-listed chemicals, so the site utilizes an Emergency Response Plan.

The stationary source and regulated substances handled [40 CFR 68.155(b)]:
The Mexichem plant located in Henry, Illinois has one regulated flammable substance identified for the Accidental Release Prevention Program (40 CFR Part 68.130) above the Threshold Quantity (TQ) of 10,000 pounds: Vinyl Chloride Monomer (VCM) (CAS No. 75-01-4).

No toxic chemicals listed in the Accidental Release Prevention Program exceed the TQ on site.

With this update, it should be noted that there was a significant increase in the VCM maximum inventory.  This was due mainly to a lengthy unexpected plant shutdown for a significant equipment repair.  Rail Cars are ordered 2-3 weeks in advance of the need and arrive approximately 2 weeks later.  During this failure, we continued to receive rail cars without consuming VCM.

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps [40 CFR 68.155(c)]:
Mexichem has in place a prevention program encompassing elements consistent with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management Standard (PSM) for Highly Hazardous Chemicals (29 CFR 1910.119). VCM, the same substance is regulated under the USEPA Clean Air Act Section 112(r)(7) Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs (RMP)(40 CFR Part 68).
The Mexichem Henry facility, which is covered under a Title V Operating Permit and the PSM and RMP standards, has implemented the following:

1. An Employee Participation policy has been instituted to regularly consult with employees regarding the development and implementation of PSM/RMP elements and hazard assessments. [40 CFR Part 68.83]

2. A comprehensive Process Safety Information program, which insures complete and accurate written information concerning process chemicals, process technology

and process equipment. This information is included in the employee training programs. [40 CFR Part 68.65]

3. Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) is conducted at least every 5 years to identify and analyze the potential hazards associated with the processing or handling of highly hazardous chemicals. [40 CFR Part 68.67]

4. The preparation of Operating Procedures that describe tasks to be performed, operating conditions to be maintained, data to be recorded, and safety precautions to be taken. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations and normal shutdown. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes. [40 CFR Part 68.69]

5.Mexichem has established Employee Training programs to insure that all employees, including maintenance and contractor employees involved with chemicals, fully understand the potential hazards of each chemical. PolyOne Corporation has established an "Operator Certification" program to train, test and certify company employees at least every three years. [40 CFR Part 68.71]

6. Contractors are thoroughly evaluated to insure that they have the appropriate job skills, knowledge and certifications to perform the job safely. [40 CFR Part 68.87]

7. For new processes, a Pre-Startup Safety Review is conducted to insure a safe transition into the normal operating mode. [40 CFR Part 68.77]

8. A Mechanical Integrity program is in place to assure the integrity of process equipment. [40 CFR Part 68.73] Elements include the following: 
-  identification and categorization of equipment and instrumentation
-  inspections and testing
-  establishment of prescribed inspection frequencies
-  development and application of pertinent maintenance procedures
-  training of maintenance personnel
-  documentation of test and inspection results
-  documentation of manufacturer's maintenance recommendatio

ns

9. A "Hot Work" Permit system is in place to manage welding, cutting or brazing of equipment in process areas. [40 CFR Part 68.85]

10. To properly manage changes involving processes, chemical, technology, equipment or facilities a Management of Change system has been implemented. [40 CFR Part 68.75]

11. In the event of any chemical release or "near miss", a team of experienced individuals familiar with the process conducts an Incident Investigation. [40 CFR Part 68.81]

12. An Emergency Response program is in place for the entire facility and the surrounding community in the event of a chemical release.

13. Compliance Audits are performed at least every 3 years to review all relevant documentation, verify process safety information, inspect the physical facilities and conduct interviews with representative plant personnel. [40 CFR Part 68.79]

The five-year accident history [40 CFR 68.155(d)]:
During the past five years, The Mexichem Henry Plant has had no chemical releases which created an emergency situation outside the plant boundaries nor resulted in any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.

The emergency response program [40 CFR 68.155(e)]:
Mexichem has in place the following "Emergency Procedures" for handling accidental releases of chemicals:
-  Fire Emergency Procedure A· Gas Alarm Procedure
-  Emergency Evacuation Procedure A· Notification Procedure
-  Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasure Plan

A notification system is in place to initiate response to any emergency. Key personnel are notified via plant alarms, Radios and telephone. Once notification has occurred, key personnel follow a series of emergency plans. For example, in the event of a fire, the Emergency Response Team will respond and an onsite Chain of Command communication system is implemented. The Emergency Response Team is trained to deal with chemical r

eleases and emergencies. Most members are trained in First Aid/CPR.

Coordinated drills with the Lacon and Henry Volunteer Fire Departments, Marshall County ESDA, and the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) are conducted to insure good communication and operational effectiveness.

Planned changes to improve safety [40 CFR 68.155(f)]:
Mexichem plans to continue to evaluate the regulated process as required under the PSM/RMP Standards to insure safe operations. Additionally, the company will continue to work with the local fire department, ESDA and LEPC to coordinate training drills and information. The Mexichem Specialty Resin Inc. annually performs a complete facility review to verify an effective Environmental, Safety and Health program.
